Your comment about co2 being dangerous just kook at Venus assumes that you consider that CO2 is responsible for the extreme temp on that planet. It is not the atmosphere gaseous content that cause the high temp but the atmospheric pressure. Given that Venus has a very slow rotation you would expect that the sun facing side would be much hotter than the dark side, but this is not the case. The temperature on Venus is uniform planet wide regardless of the solar forcing. So CO2 is not responsible for the high temperature and that is the extreme atmospheric pressure, 98 times greater that Earths. Every planet with an atmosphere has a thermocline where temperature increases the closer you get to the planet surface. You are correct to say that CO2 is not a pollutant it is a colorless odourless non toxic atmospheric gas and is essential for life on Earth, we can't do without it.

Just wanted to correct what you said about everything named "oxide" is a good oxidizer.
Actually, on the contrary. Oxide is already oxidized matter, that usually has lower energy level then it had before oxidation. But the oxides that are used as rocket fuel (like N2O4) are made in endothermic reactions, accumulating energy in their chemical bonds.

I look forward to the video that will include light pollution information about the Starlink satellites. I don't think Starlink is going to be a problem for amateur astronomers. I feel like people do not appreciate the scale of space.  From any single point on earth, you can only usefully see 0.185% (about 2 tenths of one percent) of the local sky at one particular time.  The area of earth is 196.9 million mi² (the number for low earth orbit would be larger).  Imagine spreading these tiny satellites over the surface of the earth.  You would be hard pressed to find them.

I love your optimism on Starlink.  Here is my pessimism.  1) Internet over satellite is not going to be reasonable priced. Why would they price it cheaper than data plans on cell phones? 2) Has Tesla said that the satellite receiver/transmitter will be portable?  I expect it to be like satellite cable television where you have a smallish dish.

@Tim, I am surprised that a Man who loves this Rocketry so much hasn't watched The Expanse (just wow). A show that was developed for people just like you who crave a space dwelling civilization and wanting a front row seat to the development of colonies on other solar system bodies is just crazy talk to hear you say you have never bothered to watch it. That is almost like saying you have never watched Star Trek. Wait, you have seen Star Trek's series of shows, haven't you? OK, maybe you have been far too busy for TV. But if you ever find time to sit down and watch a normal TV show PLEASE make sure it is The Expanse. The show is all about the colonization of our solar system and the very first alien encounter (alien as in life not from this Earth) and it takes place in and around the year 2350 and Mars is its own independent Planet with a Military every bit as powerful as Earth's. You are really missing out on a fun TV show that isn't based too far into the future. They even use familiar rockets still, but far better Fusion based rockets where the fuel is 150 times more energy dense per 100kg than the entire Falcon 9's total fuel capacity. Thus they almost never run out of fuel going from planet to planet. Fun TV show for sure.

Does anyone know why SpaceX no longer shows Stage One telemetry? Actually welding in space might be fairly easy. Here on earth we go to great lengths to keep the oxygen away from the molten weld puddle. If oxygen gets in contact with the weld puddle it will cause oxidation of the joint metal and a weak weld. With MIG and TIG welding we use inert gases such as carbon dioxide, argon and helium to shield the weld and keep the oxygen away. With stick welding, there is a coating around the metal rod that produces a gas when it is burned and shields the weld. It also puts a coating over the weld that protects it until the weld puddle solidifies. With no oxygen in space shielding gases should not be required. In regards to heat transfer and control of the molten weld puddle this would require testing.

Don't want to start a beef about climate change.  However, conflating Venus with what is or will occur on The Earth with regard to increasing CO2 is inaccurate, to be polite.  Not saying adding CO2 has no consequences but a run-away to a Venus is not likely.  Both worlds started out very different: bulk chemistry, volatile content (water, atmosphere), solar insolation, geologic history and just adding CO2 will not make one into the other.  It might not be pretty, but it will not be Venus or even close.  Cheers, Mark * * *
